title: 106_hr2997
content: The Act may be cited as the "Low-Income and Rural School Program" and authorizes the program. The "Low-Income and Rural School Program" Act authorizes reservations of funds for Bureau of Indian Affairs schools and grants to State educational agencies for local educational activities. The Secretary allocates funds to each State educational agency based on the number of students served by eligible local educational agencies. Specially qualified agencies in nonparticipating states can apply directly for grants under the Act. Local educational agencies can apply for grants under the Act if they meet certain criteria, including having a percentage of children from low-income families and being located in a specific community type. The Secretary may also award funds directly to specially qualified agencies in the state. Grant funds awarded to local educational agencies or schools under this Act in communities with a Rural-Urban Continuum Code of 6, 7, 8, or 9 must be used for educational technology, professional development, technical assistance, teacher recruitment and retention, parental involvement activities, or academic enrichment programs. SEC. 3. STATE DISTRIBUTION OF FUNDS. A State educational agency awards grants to local educational agencies based on competition or a formula tied to student attendance. Administrative costs are limited to 5 percent of the grant amount. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS. Each State educational agency and specially qualified agency must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant under this Act. The application should include specific measurable goals and objectives related to student academic achievement and drop-out rates. Additionally, reports must be submitted as required. Each State educational agency and specially qualified agency receiving a grant under this Act must provide an annual report to the Secretary. The report should detail the method of awarding grants, fund usage by local educational agencies and schools, and progress towards meeting goals outlined in the application. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress detailing the methods used by State educational agencies to award grants, how funds were utilized by local educational agencies and schools, and the progress made towards meeting educational goals and objectives. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "poverty line" is defined by the Office of Management and Budget, the term "specially qualified agency" refers to an eligible local educational agency, and the term "State" includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $125,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and necessary sums for the following 4 years.
